 You might want to type in "hydrogen fuel cars" in google and read up on how hydrogen is actually being used for in cars. Hint: they are not planning to 'burn' hydrogen like they do gasoline to generate power for the engine. 
 
 Also read up on "Hindenburg" to learn more about that "hydrogen" accident. Hint: the Hindenburg's skin 'coating' was flammable -- very, very, very flammable. It didn't take long for the whole airship to go down. The Hindenburg's sister airship, "Graf Zeppelin", went on to log more than a million miles. The material used to coat that ship's skin was changed after the Hindenburg accident. They still used hydrogen.
 
 And finally, in your readings, you might want to take note on the difference between hydrogen and gasoline and how they might react in an accident. Gasoline tanks have gasoline vapors. These vapors can ignite in an accident. That's why it wouldn't be a good idea to smoke at a gas station. Hydrogen, on the other hand, is a gas -- a very light gas, much lighter than gasoline vapors -- that disspates quickly, especially if they are under pressure.
